Apr 1, 2016

Matt Forte to the Jets: Analysis

He’s no Walter Payton but Matt Forte definetly played a lead role in the Bears’ offense right from the get go. His style of play was ideal for Chicago.

Let’s look at Matt Forte’s role on Chicago’s offense. Along with a high rush count, the Bears also used Forte as a short route reciever. A running back totalling 102 receptions in a year (2014) is insane. Mind you that their star reciever Alshon Jeffery (who is also remarkably talented) only saw 85 receptions that same year. Forte’s ability to rush the ball as well as create plays on short routes fit their one-dimensional offense. Highlights often show that when the pocket collapses and Cutler is being pressured, he thrived on using Forte as an escape route to avoid being sacked and gain yardage. Forte held a role on the field as a high-octane back with the ability to run routes outside the pocket and create easy pass opportunities for the QB.

Overall we can agree that Chicago has definetly made use of Forte by giving him a big role on the field. With such a high workload and dynamic style of play, he was basically playing two positions. The major issue regarding Forte’s workload is that it makes him prone to injury. He runs hard up and down the field, and as happened last year, he can occasionally aggravate a muscle. Supprisingly, he’s only missed few games in his career due to injury, and none of his injuries resulted in a Jamaal Charles or Leveon Bell like season (cut short). Unfortunately, the life span of a running back is often brief. The 30 year old RB, might not put up the numbers he used to, and may be more susceptible to injury. For Matt Forte this hasn’t been the case so far. He has yet to show fatigue on the field or show a significant drop-off on the stat sheet. Last year, he still made the top ten among running backs, despite missing three games. Some can argue that his career is reaching the beginning of the end because of his age, but let’s keep in mind that our rushing leader last year (Adrian Peterson) was also 30.

We know that Matt Forte has played the role of an 'every-down' running back with the Bears, and that he’s more than capable of doing so with the Jets. Although we are not fully aware of what the Jets will do regarding their QB situation, I have a pretty good idea of how they will use Forte. Between the butt-fumble, Tim Tebow, and Geno Smith, the Jets have had a long streak of terrible quarterbacks. Now that there is no franchise QB in the foreseeable future, the Jets have signed Forte to establish a rushing game and to create high percentage pass opportunities. I’m sure that next season we’ll see the next QB using Forte the same way that Cutler did. The signature 4 yard flick to Matt Forte will soon be adopted by the Jets offense.

Since the O-line and running back position go hand and hand, I believe that head coach Todd Bowles is building an offense based on the run. Starting with the offensive line, we know that the Jets have among one of the strongest in the league. With Nick Mangold at center, D’Brickashaw Ferguson at left tackle, and James Carpenter at left guard, the Jets have some studs on their offensive line. Even though some can argue that the right side of their line runs a little thin, this squad has only allowed 22 sacks in 2015 (second fewest in the league). Now if the Jets can agree upon new contract terms with Ferguson, this offensive line will remain a force to be reckoned with.

Fortunately, Todd Bowles may have chosen the best running back on which to build an offense. Regardless of the future QB situation in New York, Forte will be a viable option for those short and easy passes. From a stats perspective his high reception count shouldn’t change much and neither should his 200+ rush count. We all saw Chris Ivory last year, and we were all surprised by his production. If a low-celing RB like Ivory saw 247 rushes in 2015, I expect Forte to see a heavy work-load and high point production and help complete the Jets’ offense.
